linkTarget.anchoringText: The primary stress orientations and methods of determination in North America are presented in Figure 1. The study area is inside the black square in the figure. The stress orientation that dominates the area is NE-SW.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: North America Stress Map; the Willesden Green Field is shown inside the black square the Western Canada Sedimentary Basin (WCSB) ( World Stress Map, 2006 ).

formatted-caption.caption-text: North America Stress Map; the Willesden Green Field is shown inside the black square the Western Canada Sedimentary Basin (WCSB) ( World Stress Map, 2006 ).

linkTarget.bib: World Stress Map. 2006. Stress Map - North America, http://dc-app3-14.gfz potsdam.de/pub/stressmaps/america.html (accessed 5 June 2015).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Reciprocal Compressional Velocity vs Reciprocal Shear Velocity for "pure" sandstones. Best fit line developed in this paper (data points after Pickett, 1963 ).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reciprocal Compressional Velocity vs Reciprocal Shear Velocity for "pure" sandstones. Best fit line developed in this paper (data points after Pickett, 1963 ).

linkTarget.bib:
Picket and Picket, 1963 Picket
G. R. Picket
1963. Acoustic character logs and their applications in formation evaluation: Journal of Petroleum Technology ,pp . 659 667 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: The estimations of shear transit time (Δts) and shear velocity (Vs) are based on compressional logs data sonic logs and the correlation obtained by Pickett (1963) from laboratory measurements (Figure 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Calculated Pore Pressure and Minimum Horizontal Stress, interval 2108 to 2110 m. The pore pressure exceeds the minimum horizontal stress, suggesting a possible fractured zone.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Calculated Pore Pressure and Minimum Horizontal Stress, interval 2108 to 2110 m. The pore pressure exceeds the minimum horizontal stress, suggesting a possible fractured zone.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Borba et al. (2014), developed a correlation with the additional consideration of shale content in the rock. Figure 4 shows the differences between four correlations used this study for the Glauconite Formation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Unconfined rock strength (UCS) calculated from correlations developed by Borba et al. (2014) ,Onyia (1988) ,Vernik et al. (1993), and unpublished from Chang et al. (2006), sandstone interval 2105-2135 m, Willesden Green Field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Unconfined rock strength (UCS) calculated from correlations developed by Borba et al. (2014) , Onyia (1988) , Vernik et al. (1993), and unpublished from Chang et al. (2006), sandstone interval 2105-2135 m, Willesden Green Field.

linkTarget.bib:

Onyia and Onyia, 1988 Onyia

, pp. 677 680 .

, pp 223 237 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: The range of values obtained from these correlations is large, from a minimum of 31 MPa to a maximum 213 MPa. The dispersion and the values obtained are normally distributed (Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Histogram of predicted rock strength (UCS, in MPa) using 4 empirical correlations, Glauconite Formation (Table 2), Willesden Green Field. The variation is normal for depending parameters.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Histogram of predicted rock strength (UCS, in MPa) using 4 empirical correlations, Glauconite Formation (Table 2), Willesden Green Field. The variation is normal for depending parameters.

linkTarget.anchoringText: They found the static Young’s modulus to be proportional to the UCS, but with significant scatter, and elsewhere, give a proportionality ratio between 100 and 400 (Fjær, 2008). Figure 6 shows a correlation between predicted UCS (Borba et al. 2014) and Young Modulus for study interval 2105 - 2135 m in Glauconite Formation of Willesden Green Field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Correlation between predicted UCS (Borba et al. 2014) and Young Modulus for study interval 2105 - 2135 m, Glauconite Formation, Willesden Green Field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Correlation between predicted UCS (Borba et al. 2014 ) and Young Modulus for study interval 2105 - 2135 m, Glauconite Formation, Willesden Green Field.

linkTarget.bib:
Borba et al., 2014 Borba
A. M. Borba , Ferreira, F. H. Ferreira , Santos, E. S. R. Santos , Menezes, V. M. D. Menezes , and Strugale, M. 2014. UCS Estimation through Uniaxial Compressive Test, Scratch Test and Based Log Empirical Correlation. International Society for Rock Mechanics.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 7, we can observe the reduction of stress in the hydraulically fracture zone. The gap between the maximum shear stress before failure and the rock strength was reduce considerably, meanwhile, the pore pressure and the minimum horizontal stress increase.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Shear stress for failure variation and UCS as a function of depth. The stress window is considerably reduced in the hydraulically fractured interval, and the reopening stress required for reopening decreases.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Shear stress for failure variation and UCS as a function of depth. The stress window is considerably reduced in the hydraulically fractured interval, and the reopening stress required for reopening decreases.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 8, the Mohr-Coulomb Diagram is estimated with the predicted values of UCS and the limits of minimum horizontal stress. The failure envelopes are traced with a top at the maximum angle of friction before failure at 1.0 (black dash line).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Mohr-Coulomb envelopes calculated with the predicted UCS. Blue open dots correspond to shear stress and net stress estimated for the Glauconite Formation. The different circles are determined using the mean of the UCS at the study interval. In order to determinate possible failure scenarios at several stress magnitudes, with higher internal coefficients angles, the fracturing pressure required is lower.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mohr-Coulomb envelopes calculated with the predicted UCS. Blue open dots correspond to shear stress and net stress estimated for the Glauconite Formation. The different circles are determined using the mean of the UCS at the study interval. In order to determinate possible failure scenarios at several stress magnitudes, with higher internal coefficients angles, the fracturing pressure required is lower.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 9a, the critically stress fractures are presented in a Mohr-Coulomb Diagram, therefore, theses fractures are considered mechanically or hydraulically active, and conductive with high permeabilities.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: A) The left hand side of the figure shows active and open fractures calculated with the UCS. Blue open dots correspond to shear stress and net stress in relationship of overburden stress, all estimated for the Glauconite Formation. Dash lines delimitates the area of stressed fractures for coefficient of angle of friction between 0.6 and 1.0. The different circles are determined by the unconfined stress variations. B) The right hand side of the figure shows the angle of friction (orange line) is lower in the hydraulically fractured interval also with coefficients of angle friction between 0.6 and 1.0.

formatted-caption.caption-text: A) The left hand side of the figure shows active and open fractures calculated with the UCS. Blue open dots correspond to shear stress and net stress in relationship of overburden stress, all estimated for the Glauconite Formation. Dash lines delimitates the area of stressed fractures for coefficient of angle of friction between 0.6 and 1.0. The different circles are determined by the unconfined stress variations. B) The right hand side of the figure shows the angle of friction (orange line) is lower in the hydraulically fractured interval also with coefficients of angle friction between 0.6 and 1.0.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 shows the limits of stress magnitudes defined by frictional faulting theory in strike-slip faulting regime, assuming hydrostatic and pore pressure.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Limits of stress magnitudes defined by frictional faulting theory in strike-slip faulting regime assuming hydrostatic and pore pressure. The green line represents the maximum horizontal stress (Shmax), in yellow is the minimum value of the least principal stress (Shmin), in blue the pore pressure.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Limits of stress magnitudes defined by frictional faulting theory in strike-slip faulting regime assuming hydrostatic and pore pressure. The green line represents the maximum horizontal stress (Shmax), in yellow is the minimum value of the least principal stress (Shmin), in blue the pore pressure.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In order to analyze the results, a stress polygon for the Glauconite Formation at 2108 m is presented (Figure 11).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Limits on stress magnitudes defined by frictional faulting theory, the green line indicates the maximum value of Shmax for reverse faulting, the blue line the Shmax for a normal faulting environments, an in the red line the limit of Shmax for Strike-Slip faulting plane. The dash lines indicates the limits of tensile fractures induce by hydraulically fracturing, and high, low and mean values of UCS are plotted in order to visualize the possible variations due to a poor prediction of rock strength with a fixed wellbore breakout angle at 0 degrees.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Limits on stress magnitudes defined by frictional faulting theory, the green line indicates the maximum value of Shmax for reverse faulting, the blue line the Shmax for a normal faulting environments, an in the red line the limit of Shmax for Strike-Slip faulting plane. The dash lines indicates the limits of tensile fractures induce by hydraulically fracturing, and high, low and mean values of UCS are plotted in order to visualize the possible variations due to a poor prediction of rock strength with a fixed wellbore breakout angle at 0 degrees.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12 shows variations of the wellbore angle (wBO). Results of this sensitivity analysis confirm the low-stress profile in the well at the moment in which it was hydraulically fractured. The change between the angles from 0 to 60 degrees is less than 10 MPa.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Polygon which defines possible stress magnitudes at 2108 m with the limits of magnitude for the principal faulting regimes, tensile fractures and the different angles of wellbore breakouts are plotted in order to visualize the possible angle induced with the fracturing operations.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Polygon which defines possible stress magnitudes at 2108 m with the limits of magnitude for the principal faulting regimes, tensile fractures and the different angles of wellbore breakouts are plotted in order to visualize the possible angle induced with the fracturing operations.
